A **clay golem**, ', is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned") [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") that is one of the stronger varities a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") can encounter, but is slightly weaker than the [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem").

A clay golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") like all golems. A clay golem that is subjected to [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") will become a [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) A clay golem that is hit by a beam from the [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation") or the [cancellation](/wiki/Spellbook_of_cancellation "Spellbook of cancellation") spell, or else is hit by the [intrinsic theft](/wiki/Intrinsic_theft "Intrinsic theft") attack of a [gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin"), is instantly destroyed.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) A [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") in the form of a clay golem that is subjected to the 1⁄10 chance of intrinsic theft from a gremlin is returned to normal form, even if they are wearing an [amulet of unchanging](/wiki/Amulet_of_unchanging "Amulet of unchanging");[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) a hero in clay golem form that is cancelled by the wand or spell will return to normal form, or else die as normal if they have [unchanging](/wiki/Unchanging "Unchanging").[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Generation

Randomly generated clay golems are always created hostile. Clay golems are always generated with 50 [hit points](/wiki/Hit_point "Hit point").[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

Clay golems can generate as a result of [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") if there are enough [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper"), [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver"), [platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum"), [gemstone](/wiki/Gemstone "Gemstone"), or [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") objects in a pile of items.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Clay golems leave behind 51-69 [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock") upon death [instead of a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) They are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit a1b76593](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/a1b765936f807729e1c2cf3c7a9b928e34a277f5), clay golems generate with 70 HP.

## Strategy

Clay golems hit decently hard, but are also quite slow at 7 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") - a clay golem is not too difficult to defeat if a hero can maintain distance long enough and/or have enough [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") to reduce their damage.

## History

The clay golem first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, casting [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") at a [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") or [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a golem produces a single [meatball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball"), since any golem other than the [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem") or [leather golem](/wiki/Leather_golem "Leather golem") is considered "[vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian")" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") via [commit d8a0f734](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4) so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"), including some variants based on those versions, a hero being cancelled while in clay golem form will always return to their base form, even if they have unchanging - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2") via [commit 89237fc9](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/89237fc96d9632a29474d7f61d906480ba71a931).

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Golem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem "wikipedia:Golem")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Creation of life from clay](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creation_of_life_from_clay "wikipedia:Creation of life from clay")***

The *gōlem*, originating from Jewish folklore, is an animate, anthropomorphic being usually created entirely from clay (or mud). One of the oldest Talmudic stories describes Adam as a golem, initially created when his mud (or "dust") was "kneaded into a shapeless husk" - similar tales and motifs of the creation of the first man and/or humankind from clay exist in several world religions and mythologies.

The most famous golem narrative, "The Golem of Prague", is generally believed to be a product of early 19th-century German literature: in the late 16th century, the rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel reportedly built a golem from clay gathered at the banks of the Vltava River, and brought it to life through rituals and Hebrew incantations to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. Golems in this and various other tales are inscribed with Hebrew words that animate them; one particular example is the word *emét* (אמת, "truth" in Hebrew), which could be used to deactivate the golem by removing the *aleph* (א) from the word, changing the inscription to *mét* (מת, "dead"). The clay golems of *NetHack* are implied to be constructed similarly, since cancellation destroys them instantly by erasing writing from their heads.

Clay golems appear in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where they debut in the 1st Edition *Monster Manual*. Clay golems can be created by high-level clerics through the use of several spells on a humanoid clay statue, which is animated using an elemental spirit from the Plane of Earth. While animate, the golem is under the command of the cleric that created it, and is only vulnerable to blunt magical weapons and very specific (usually earth-based) spells. However, similar to some of the classic golem tales that inspired it, there is an increasing chance each round that the golem goes berserk, causing it to attack any and every living thing until it is destroyed; this can also occur if the golem is sufficiently damaged.

## Messages

- \<The clay golem> is heating up!

  A clay golem was hit by a flaming attack.

* Some writing vanishes from the clay golem's head!

  A clay golem was hit with a cancellation spell, beam or attack - this instantly destroys it.

* Some writing vanishes from your head!

  You were polymorphed into a clay golem and hit with one of the above effects. This will return you to your original form, unless you have with unchanging.

* You have a strangely sad feeling for a moment, then it passes.

  Your [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") clay golem was canceled and destroyed by a gremlin.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), clay golems are always generated with 150 HP.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), the [Chaos Temple variant](/wiki/Chaos_Temple_Quest "Chaos Temple Quest") of the [Chaos Quest](/wiki/Chaos_Quest_\(dNetHack\) "Chaos Quest (dNetHack)") generates six clay golems within the exterior of the 'past' Temple of Chaos at level creation.

One of the special levels in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") included from the [Heck² patch](/wiki/Heck%C2%B2_patch "Heck² patch") generates five clay golems at level creation.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), the clay golem's glyph is changed to *'*.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), clay golems always generate with 70 HP.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, one of the special levels in Gehennom included from the Heck² patch generates three stone golems at level creation, as in dNetHack and its variants.

## Encyclopedia entry

It was a warm spring night when a fist knocked at the door so  
hard that the hinges bent.  
A man opened it and peered out into the street. There was  
mist coming off the river and it was a cloudy night. He might  
as well have tried to see through white velvet.  
But he thought afterwards that there had been shapes out  
there, just beyond the light spilling out into the road. A  
lot of shapes, watching him carefully. He thought maybe  
there'd been very faint points of light...  
There was no mistaking the shape right in front of him,  
though. It was big and dark red and looked like a child's  
clay model of a man. Its eyes were two embers.

\[ Feet of Clay, by Terry Pratchett ]

A '''clay golem''', {{monsym|clay golem}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a [[thick-skinned]] [[golem]] that is one of the stronger varities a [[hero]] can encounter, but is slightly weaker than the [[stone golem]].

A clay golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [[sleep resistance]] and [[poison resistance]] like all golems. A clay golem that is subjected to [[stoning]] will become a [[stone golem]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2525|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} A clay golem that is hit by a beam from the [[wand of cancellation]] or the {{+ of|cancellation}} spell, or else is hit by the [[intrinsic theft]] attack of a [[gremlin]], is instantly destroyed.{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1252|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|1832|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} A [[hero]] in the form of a clay golem that is subjected to the {{frac|10}} chance of intrinsic theft from a gremlin is returned to normal form, even if they are wearing an [[amulet of unchanging]];{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|1537|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} a hero in clay golem form that is cancelled by the wand or spell will return to normal form, or else die as normal if they have [[unchanging]].{{refsrc|src/zap.c|2764|nethack=3.6.7}}

==Generation==
Randomly generated clay golems are always created hostile. Clay golems are always generated with 50 [[hit point]]s.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1985|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Clay golems can generate as a result of [[polypiling]] if there are enough [[copper]], [[silver]], [[platinum]], [[gemstone]], or [[mineral]] objects in a pile of items.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|1306|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Clay golems leave behind 51-69 [[rock]]s upon death [[Corpseless|instead of a corpse]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|391|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are not a valid target for [[genocide]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Per {{commit|a1b765936f807729e1c2cf3c7a9b928e34a277f5}}, clay golems generate with 70 HP.}}

==Strategy==
Clay golems hit decently hard, but are also quite slow at 7 [[speed]] - a clay golem is not too difficult to defeat if a hero can maintain distance long enough and/or have enough [[AC]] to reduce their damage.

==History==
The clay golem first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including some variants based on those versions, casting [[stone to flesh]] at a [[statue]] or [[figurine]] of a golem produces a single [[meatball]], since any golem other than the [[flesh golem]] or [[leather golem]] is considered "[[vegetarian]]" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] via {{commit|d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4}} so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [[NetHack 3.6.1]], including some variants based on those versions, a hero being cancelled while in clay golem form will always return to their base form, even if they have unchanging - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.2]] via {{commit|89237fc96d9632a29474d7f61d906480ba71a931}}.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Golem}}
{{wikipedia|Creation of life from clay}}
The ''gōlem'', originating from Jewish folklore, is an animate, anthropomorphic being usually created entirely from clay (or mud). One of the oldest Talmudic stories describes Adam as a golem, initially created when his mud (or "dust") was "kneaded into a shapeless husk" - similar tales and motifs of the creation of the first man and/or humankind from clay exist in several world religions and mythologies.

The most famous golem narrative, "The Golem of Prague", is generally believed to be a product of early 19th-century German literature: in the late 16th century, the rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel reportedly built a golem from clay gathered at the banks of the Vltava River, and brought it to life through rituals and Hebrew incantations to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. Golems in this and various other tales are inscribed with Hebrew words that animate them; one particular example is the word ''emét'' (אמת, "truth" in Hebrew), which could be used to deactivate the golem by removing the ''aleph'' (א) from the word, changing the inscription to ''mét'' (מת, "dead"). The clay golems of ''NetHack'' are implied to be constructed similarly, since cancellation destroys them instantly by erasing writing from their heads.

Clay golems appear in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', where they debut in the 1st Edition ''Monster Manual''. Clay golems can be created by high-level clerics through the use of several spells on a humanoid clay statue, which is animated using an elemental spirit from the Plane of Earth. While animate, the golem is under the command of the cleric that created it, and is only vulnerable to blunt magical weapons and very specific (usually earth-based) spells. However, similar to some of the classic golem tales that inspired it, there is an increasing chance each round that the golem goes berserk, causing it to attack any and every living thing until it is destroyed; this can also occur if the golem is sufficiently damaged.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], clay golems are always generated with 150 HP.{{refsrc|makemon.c|2252|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], the [[Chaos Temple Quest|Chaos Temple variant]] of the [[Chaos Quest (dNetHack)|Chaos Quest]] generates six clay golems within the exterior of the 'past' Temple of Chaos at level creation.

One of the special levels in [[Gehennom]] included from the [[Heck² patch]] generates five clay golems at level creation. 

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], the clay golem's glyph is changed to {{red|<u>'</u>}}.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], clay golems always generate with 70 HP.

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, one of the special levels in Gehennom included from the Heck² patch generates three stone golems at level creation, as in dNetHack and its variants.
